SEARCH
Package sh.brane.core

Class AnsiColors

java.lang.Object
sh.brane.core.AnsiColors
public final class AnsiColors extends Object
Modern, curated ANSI color palette for terminal output with automatic TTY detection.

This class provides a sophisticated color scheme designed for modern terminal logging, moving away from traditional primary colors to a more refined palette. Colors are automatically disabled when not running in a TTY environment unless FORCE_COLOR=true is set.

Color Philosophy

  • TEAL - Success indicators (instead of traditional green)
  • CORAL - Error indicators (instead of traditional red)
  • INDIGO - Informational messages (instead of traditional blue)
  • AMBER - Warnings and gas-related operations (instead of yellow)
  • LAVENDER - Transaction operations
  • SLATE - Metadata and secondary information

Usage Example


 // Manual coloring
 System.out.println(AnsiColors.TEAL + "Success!" + AnsiColors.RESET);

 // Using helper methods
 System.out.println(AnsiColors.success("Operation completed"));
 System.out.println(AnsiColors.error("Operation failed"));

All public constants in this class are safe to concatenate with strings for terminal output. Colors automatically no-op when not in a TTY environment.

Since:
0.1.0-alpha
See Also:

  • Field Details

    • IS_TTY

      public static final boolean IS_TTY
      Whether standard output is a TTY (terminal) environment.

      This is determined in the following order:

      1. If system property brane.force.color=true is set, colors are enabled (useful for testing)
      2. If environment variable FORCE_COLOR=true is set, colors are enabled (for CI/CD pipelines)
      3. If System.console() is non-null, colors are enabled (interactive terminal)
      4. Otherwise, colors are disabled

      Other classes should use this constant instead of duplicating the TTY detection logic.

    • RESET

      public static final String RESET
      ANSI reset code - clears all formatting

  • Method Details

    • hash

      public static String hash(String value)
      Shortens a hash or address value for readable log display.

      Values longer than 16 characters are shortened to show the first 10 characters (including "0x" prefix) followed by "..." and the last 4 characters. For example, a 66-character hash becomes: 0x12345678...abcd

      Parameters:
      value - the hash or address value to format
      Returns:
      the shortened value, or "null" if value is null

    • duration

      public static String duration(long micros)
      Formats a duration in microseconds as a human-readable string.
      Parameters:
      micros - duration in microseconds
      Returns:
      formatted duration (e.g., "1.5ms" or "2.3s")

    • num

      public static String num(Object value)
      Converts a numeric value to string.
      Parameters:
      value - the value to convert
      Returns:
      string representation of the value

    • kv

      public static String kv(String key, String value)
      Formats a key-value pair with colored key.
      Parameters:
      key - the key name
      value - the value
      Returns:
      formatted "key value" with colored key

    • success

      public static String success(String message)

      Parameters:
